intro: Eriocaulon arechavaletae, commonly known as the Andean spikerush, is a member of the Cyperaceae family, characterized by its grass-like appearance and aquatic or semi-aquatic habitat. It typically grows in wetlands, marshes, and along the edges of streams and lakes, where it thrives in moist, nutrient-rich soils. The plant has narrow, erect stems with small, spike-like inflorescences that bear tiny, wind-pollinated flowers. Its leaves are usually linear and arranged in two rows, contributing to its distinctive appearance. Eriocaulon arechavaletae plays an important ecological role in stabilizing wetland soils and providing habitat for various microorganisms and invertebrates.
